Sistersville plant. As defined by the regulations, the Sistersville plant stores the following toxic 
chemicals in excess of the threshold quantities: anhydrous ammonia, acrylonitrile,

General Accidental Release Prevention Program
The Sistersville plant maintains a rigorous Process Safety Management program, which satisfies 
all applicable requirements of both OSHA's Process Safety Management Rule 29 CFR 1910.119 
and EPA's Risk Management Rule 40 CFR 68. MPM maintains policies/programs, which address 
required program elements. These policies and procedures include: employee participation, 
process safety information, process hazard analysis, operating procedures, employee training, a 
qualified contractor program, pre-startup safety review, mechanical integrity, safe work practices, 
incident investigation, trade secrets, and an emergency response program.
MPM encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety and accident prevention 
programs. Examples include participation in process hazard analysis, operating procedure 
development, incident investigations, unsafe condition reporting, Central Safety team meetings, 
management of change reviews, etc. Employees and their representatives have access to all 
information required by 40 CFR 68. Process safety information is compiled prior to beginning any 
Process Hazard Analysis, Differential Process Hazard Analysis or revalidation effort to assure 
proper documentation is available for review team

made at time of the day or night in accordance with OSHA and EPA requirements. 
MPM investigates all incidents and near misses in a timely fashion, which meets or exceeds all 
OSHA and EPA requirements utilizing a multi-discipline team approach. Management 
representatives participate in incident reviews based upon the severity of the event. The 
investigation reports include date of the incident, date the investigation began, incident description, 
factors contributing to the incident, and recommendations to prevent the incident(s) from 
reoccurring. Investigation findings are reviewed with effected personnel, including applicable 
contractors and are retained for at least five years.
MPM maintains a program to allow employees access to information considered as trade secret 
upon request of the employee. MPM undergoes qualifying process safety audits every 3 years in 
accordance with OSHA and EPA requirements. Additional audits are performed on a periodic 
basis through the plants internal audit program. MPM prepares reports of the audit findings and 
retains the two most recent reports and documents responses to compliance audit findings and 
corrects deficiencies.
MPM maintains the ongoing integrity of the equipment through its mechanical integrity program. 
Chemical processes are well documented through R&D Definitions of Technology, which are 
shared with operating departments prior to implementation of a new process. Primary mitigation 
for hazard events is relief devices, water spray, foam protection and secondary containment. Major 
process hazards identified by PHA teams are documented in mandatory Operational Safety 
Standards that define to operations the required mitigations to prevent hazardous situations. The 
facilities main operational areas are run and monitored utilizing computerized process control 
systems to ensure that any deviations from the intended safe operating conditions (e.g., pressure, 
temperature, flow rate,

etc.) are immediately identified and corrected.
Five-Year Accidental Release History 
MPM has had no releases in the last five years, which meet the criteria for accidental release 
reporting as defined within 40 CFR 68.42. 
Emergency Response Program 
MPM maintains a written emergency response program designed to protect workers, the public 
and the environment in the event of a major accidental release. As part of this program, we have 
developed and implemented written programs to train all our employees in the proper response to 
an incident. The site has also developed and trained more extensively a smaller number of 
employees to act as an emergency brigade to provide more expertise in responding to more 
significant events both on and off site. This brigade is equipped with equipment needed to respond 
to emergencies. MPM maintains a trained emergency brigade on site 24 hours per day, seven days 
a week. MPM has emergency plans and procedures in place and has communicated those with 
local regulating agencies. Mutual aid agreements exist with both neighboring communities and 
industrial entities in the region. 
Planned Changes to Improve Safety 
Sistersville has several elements of the management system of the accident prevent program in 
place for continuing sitewide safety improvement. The following elements of the PSM/RMP plans 
are used to improve safety for workers and ensure protection of the environment: Process Hazard 
Analysis (PHA), Management of Change (MOC), Compliance Audits, and Training Programs.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Accidental Release and Emergency Response Policies 
The Accidental Release Prevention (ARP) requirements mandated in Section 112r of the 1990 
Clean Air Act Amendments were promulgated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) on 
June 20, 1996. These requirements are codified in 40 CFR 68, Subparts A through H. Under the 
ARP program, processes with chemical quantities on site exceeding the listed threshold quantities 
have applicable requirements. The Sistersville plant has a long-standing commitment to worker 
and public safety, and environmental stewardship. This commitment is demonstrated by the 
resources invested in safety and environmental protection, employee safety training, and safety in 
the design, installation, operation and maintenance of plant equipment. Sistersville has 
implemented reasonable controls to prevent and mitigate probable releases of hazardous 
chemicals. Should a release occur, trained personnel would promptly respond to control and 
contain the release while coordinating with local emergency responders.
Description of the Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances 
The Sistersville plant is a silicone chemical producing facility located at 10851 Energy Highway, 
Friendly, West Virginia. The plant is situated on approximately 1400 acres in southern Tyler 
County. An industrial park containing a contract chemical manufacturer, environmental 
remediation firm and an aluminum dross-recycling firm to the south, the Ohio River to the west, a 
rural residential area to the north and undeveloped forestland to the east occupy the immediate 
area surrounding the facility. Silicone chemicals have been manufactured at MPM since the mid-1950s. 
The Sistersville plant makes a variety of silicone products, which fall into three general 
categories: urethane additives, silicone fluids and silanes. The products are utilized in a broad 
spectrum of industry. MPM is operated 24 hours a day, seven days per we

loyees.
MPM maintains a procedure for construction of operating procedures, which includes all 
requirements specified by OSHA and EPA. Annual reviews are conducted as required. Operating 
procedures are reviewed and updated as required by the management of change process and 
through suggestions made by operators. The procedures are consistent with the PSI, and address: 
initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, and startup 
following a shutdown. Operating limits, safety and health considerations, control measures, and 
quality control of raw materials are also covered. The operating procedures are readily available 
to employees who work on the processes. Safe work practices are established and communicated 
to employees and contractors to control hazards during operations.
MPM maintains a written and walkthrough training program for operations, maintenance and 
distribution personnel. Facility personnel undergo training on OSHA, EPA and DOT required 
subjects on an ongoing basis. Operations and maintenance personnel have received both overview 
training as well as specific process hazards overview training. Initial training in the process and 
operating procedures occurs prior to working on the process Refresher training is conducted every 
three years. MPM documents each employee involved in process training.
MPM maintains a contractor qualification program, which meets all OSHA and EPA requirements. 
Contractors receive hazard identification training prior to commencement of work and are 
monitored by the internal auditing program to assure compliance with all OSHA, EPA and 
corporate standards. MPM informs contractors of known potential fire, explosion, and toxic release 
hazards associated with the contractor's work and the process. MPM has processes to assure that 
the contractors are trained in the necessary safe work practices and documents contractor 
identification, date of training, and other mea

s' utilization during the Process Hazard Analysis 
process. Process safety information includes information on the hazards of the regulated 
substances in the processes including toxicity information, permissible exposure limits, physical 
data, reactivity data, corrosivity data, thermal and chemical stability data, and potential hazardous 
effects of inadvertent mixing. MPM also compiles written information the technologies of the 
process including process chemistry, process diagrams, maximum process inventory, and 
evaluation of consequences of deviation. MPM also compiles information the equipment in the 
process, including materials of construction, P&ID's, electrical classifications, design codes, and 
safety systems. Process safety information is kept evergreen through the utilization of the 
management of change process as well as periodic internal and corporate audit verifications.
MPM maintains a procedure to assure PHA's and revalidations are conducted within prescribed 
timeframes. PHA's are conducted anytime a process or system has been modified significantly. A 
management system is in place to document and track PHA actions to timely completion, assigning 
resources as needed to maintain demonstrable progress. The PHA's are completed appropriately to 
the processes identified and are evaluated to control the hazards involved in the processes. The 
PHA addresses hazards of the process, previous incidents with potential for catastrophic 
consequences, engineering and administrative controls such as detection to provide early warning, 
consequences of failure of engineering and administrative controls, stationary source siting, human 
factors, and qualitative evaluation of a range of possible safety and health effects of failure of
controls. MPM has a system to address the PHA findings, document the resolution and actions to 
be taken, and develops a written schedule for completing actions, and to communicate actions to 
effected emp

ns to verify training. Contractors are required to 
advise MPM of unique hazards posed by the contract work or hazards found by contractor's work.
MPM maintains an active program to perform pre-startup safety review on all changes to assure 
that all phases of the change have been installed correctly, personnel trained as required, and 
maintenance procedures are in place to safely maintain the equipment. The pre-startup review 
confirms the following prior to introduction of regulated substances: construction and equipment 
are in accordance with design specifications, adequate safety, operating, maintenance and 
emergency procedures and in place, PHA's are performed, and resolutions implemented, and that 
training of each employee involved is completed.
MPM maintains an extensive mechanical integrity program, which covers not only regulated 
equipment but also all other equipment at the site. Routine maintenance procedures are in place 
for critical equipment and tests required complying with PSM and RMP, following manufacturer 
recommendations. Inspections and tests are performed on process equipment and follow 
recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices. The person inspecting and testing 
the process equipment is competent to the components being inspected. Deficiencies are identified 
by inspections or tests are corrected before use or in a timely and safe manner. MPM assures that 
spare parts and maintenance materials are suitable for the application in which it is to be used for.
MPM maintains safe work practice policies, which govern hot work, confined space, master 
tag/lockout, and line breaking which meets or exceeds all OSHA and EPA requirements. 
Compliance with these procedures is assured through the plants internal auditing processes, 
including internal audits, management walkthroughs, procedural audits, etc. Management of 
Change- MPM maintains an active management of change process, which governs all changes
